results.title: Dog's heaven
results.creator_credit: H Tyrlova and Short Film Studio
results.brief_description: Using wool fibre, a flexible material for animation, this film tells the story of a little black dog, slightly disappointed in his master, who has a brief sojourn in Dog’s Heaven. Instrumentation comes from three harpists, trumpeters, double bassists and a chorus.

results.title: Does Dracula have Aids?
results.creator_credit: John Lander, Ken Chown and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
AIDS is the most publicised and least understood disease in Australia. This video may help to clear up some of the confusion as the discoverer of the AIDS virus, Professor Luc Montagnier, joins Australia’s most experienced AIDS specialists and community leaders to confront the ethical and social dilemmas created by the disease. Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypothetical on AIDS was filmed on 12th August, 1986.

results.title: Does anybody need me anymore?
results.creator_credit: Paul Bogart and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Part of the “Being a woman” series. Observes the changes which occur in the marriage of a middle-aged couple when the wife decides to change her own lifestyle after her children are grown and gone. Raises issues regarding women’s roles, sex-role stereotyping, changing expectaions of the female role and the male perception of such topics.

results.title: Does advertising pay?
results.creator_credit: Alan Strowger, Tony Matthews and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Marketing”.
In 1965 British industry spent nearly 600 million pounds on advertising and sales promotion. Was the money well spent? Part of a series of films designed to present the theory and practice of modern marketing. Case histories of branded products (failures as well as successes) are given to illustrate particular market problems.

results.title: Dodging the column
results.brief_description: The transporting of a distillation column, 137 feet long, 500 miles by road from Greenwich to Grangemouth in Scotland. The commentary, spoken by the rigger in charge and one of the tractor drivers, expresses the humour and resourcefulness with which these transport workers tackle their job. The camera has captured moments of beauty as well as some amusing episodes in this journey of the longest load to travel by road in England.
results.description: The transporting of a distillation column, 137 feet long, 500 miles by road from Greenwich to Grangemouth in Scotland. results.title: Dodge your debts
results.brief_description: A fast paced slapstick farce starring Gaylord Lloyd (Harold Lloyd’s brother). Set in England, involves a debt collector, scores of bobbys, a pub, a thug and his beautiful daughter. Cast also includes William Gillespie, Estelle Harrison, George Rowe.

results.title: Documentary of achievement
results.brief_description: The story of the development of the South African Iron and Steel Industrial Corporation. The film illustrates the growth of the vast iron and steel company and shows the part it has played in the development of South Africa through two generations in both peace and war. Contains excellent footage of construction of vehicles and ammunition for the war and some spectacular dangerous footage as well.

results.title: Documentary
results.creator_credit: Herman J. Engel, Sonya Friedman and Texture Films
results.brief_description: A compilation film of major sequences from famous documentaries. Each sequence offers an important example of documentary style, content and construction. A brief introduction prior to each segment provides a historical context. This film is also available for loan in 3 parts: 1922-1939 (506297), 1935-1955 (506298), 1948-1976 (506299).

results.title: Doctor woman: life and times of Elizabeth Bagshaw
results.creator_credit: Mark McCurdy, Beryl Fox and Lockwood Films
results.brief_description: A forerunner of the women’s movement, Elizabeth Bagshaw was one of the first women to practice medicine in Canada. In having to overcome society’s bias against women in medicine she helped to instigate changes in public opinion on that issue as well as the issue of birth control. The film captures the personality of this remarkable woman through a contemporary interview and re-enactments of episodes from her youth. The sepia tones of the re-enactments are in keeping with the film techniques of the time, giving the viewer a strong sense of the period. The film is of special interest to people interested in the evolution of woman’s roles in Canadian society. (Awards: Toronto; Columbus)
